segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn at the Berkeley American Astronomical Society meeting, June 10th, 1993, and I'm talking with Brad Smith.
Brad, for the record, would you give your full name?
Bradford A. Smith.
Okay, when did you get into planetary astronomy?
Okay, and where and doing what?
I was in the Army and assigned to work with Clyde Tombaugh at Lowell Observatory in what was then the New Mexico College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts.
Tombaugh was conducting a search for earth-orbiting satellites, small earth-orbiting satellites, and the Army Map Service, specifically John O'Keefe, sent me to
to the southwest to work with Tombaugh.

When you first broke into the racket, were you aware of any bias against the planetary solar system work on the part of real astronomers, say, for example, people that work on galaxies or stars and mountains and various other places?
Hey, I started off with Tombaugh.
I was thrown into the bias issue right at the very beginning.
and had other contacts with Kuiper.
So I was very familiar with the bias against so-called planetary astronomy.
Do you think any of that had to do with the fact that there was kind of an instrumental barrier?
Namely, infrared detectors were junk, and that's where the spectral information was.
Photometry was pretty poor to get any information out of that.
Or was it personal?
Or was it Percival Lowell?
Or was it a combination?
I think people like Lowell probably had some effect on this attitude, but the attitude seemed to be a fairly general one.
That is, people who study the planets just aren't doing serious astronomy.
By the way, those tendencies continue today.
Many astronomers feel that if you're not doing cosmological extragalactic astronomy and just playing around our own galaxy, you're not doing serious astronomy.
So these things just come about depending upon what's in vogue at the time.
Do you think planetary astronomy is astronomy?
Of course it's astronomy.
Do you think the general public thinks planetary astronomy is astronomy?
Very definitely.
When did you first cross paths with NSA?
With NASA?
When they were created.
In what way?
Tombo and I both had proposals and we were funded very early on, I guess among the very first NASA grants that were provided by the fledgling NASA.
Do you remember what that was for?
Yeah, I can remember what some of them were for.

We had, both Tombo and I, had come to the conclusion, I'm sure others as well, that the planetary work that was being done at Lowell and Lick and various other places, they tend to concentrate on taking observations, photographs, when everything was just right.
You know, a close Mars opposition, when Jupiter was in opposition.
And I wanted to get involved in synoptic observations, to look at the planets every night, whether it was good seeing or bad seeing, whether it was close to opposition or far.
And so we put in a proposal to do this using a telescope that was left over from Tombaugh's satellite search program.
That was the basis of the original support from NASA.
Where do you think planetary astronomy would be today without the money that NASA has spent on it in the last 30 years?
Well, that's a little hard to judge.

I mean, after all, if NASA were to stop their support right now, there would be a real hiatus in ground-based planetary astronomy because the NSF doesn't have a recent history of supporting planetary astronomy.
I really don't know.
Planets became more important as the technology developed to study them.
And if there had been no NASA, I would guess that at some level, the NSF would have provided support for studies of planets.
But without question, it was boosted by NASA's need to have ground-based support for their flight programs.
In general, how's your relationship been with NASA?
In other words, do you have any compliments, any gripes?
No, I've had a very good relationship with NASA.
Money is always short, and there's always a fight for funds.
And the problems become exacerbated when the funding really drops down as it is right now.
But I certainly don't have any long-term complaints, no.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job of selling themselves to the public and to Congress?
I think they've done an especially good job.
I know many people in the astrophysics area who sort of look at solar system astronomers as a model for what they should be doing in trying to promote programs and get support.
It's been 30 years now of modern planetary astronomy, or more.

And both from the ground and from space probes and from landings and everything, we haven't found a single trace of present or past life anywhere in the solar system except Earth, and in particular no little green man on Mars.
Do you think that's had a negative effect on public support and financial support for planetary science?
I think the public fairly quickly forgets the negative results.
Certainly in the post-Viking era, I'm sure there was a lot of public disappointment over Viking's failure to find life on Mars.
On the other hand, I
believe, as do many, that the experiments designed for carrying out a search for life on Mars were not optimized.
And at some point, we're going to go out and do it again and hopefully do it right next time.
And I think when this program becomes common knowledge, that once again, you'll see the public lining up with great interest to see what comes out of it.
Thirty years ago, if this would be an American Astronomical Society, meaning everybody would be here.
Since then, the planetary astronomers, among others, have had their own sub-society, the Division for Planetary Sciences.
American planetary astronomers have their own journal now, Icarus.
Have these developments been good or bad for planetary astronomy and astronomy in general?
I think it's been good for both.
One sees the occasional planetary astronomer or planetary scientist at the full-up AAS meetings and an occasional paper sometimes because it's just the right time to present it.
But getting planetary astronomers together and getting their own publication, I think, has been beneficial both to the group as a whole and to astronomy in general.
Where are you now?
Where am I now besides sitting here talking to you?
You mean my institutional affiliation?
Yes, I'm with the Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii.
How long have you been there?
I've been there almost three years now.
Where were you before that?
Before that, I was at the University of Arizona.
I was there for 15 years.
From when to when?
From 1973, 74, I can't remember exactly, until 1990.
Okay, and what part of the University of Arizona?
Oh, in the planetary sciences department.
I also had a joint appointment within the astronomy department.
One place that you're associated with, in my mind, is New Mexico State University.
And when did you get associated with that?
Well, my association began, actually, when I went to work with Tombaugh in 1955.
When I got out of the Army in 1957, I elected to stay on in Massachusetts and spent some time working with Tombaugh.
At that time, we were supported by Air Force funds, and they were fairly meager.
So I spent a little time working with the rocket facility at the Physical Sciences Laboratory.
But then shortly after that, NASA came into existence, funding became available, and I went back to doing astronomy again with Tombaugh.
Now, you folks built that up quite a bit.
How long were you at New Mexico State, and when did you leave there?
I was there for about 17, 18 years from, well, as soon as I got out of the Army, 57, until...
So you can see the lift and pick workout, right?
Yeah, until 1973 or thereabouts.
And you actually built that up to a fairly good-sized department, didn't you?
We did, yeah.
What's happened to it since?
It's still going.
There is still a fairly strong planetary commitment there.
Rita Beebe pretty much took over for me when I left, and as the planetary patrol that we initiated...
back in the mid to late 50s is still going and still being supported.
I should have asked you at the beginning, when were you born and where?
I was born in 1931 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
What do you think is the most important piece of work in planetary astronomy that you've done?
I mean, either research or building a department or preventing a fight or whatever.
Well, you know, it's been a lot of things.
I've been in this for a long time, really getting old now.
I mean, for example, the planetary patrol that we initiated almost immediately began to produce results just because of the synoptic studies.
We essentially co-discovered the...
the four-day rotation of the high atmosphere winds on Venus.
We discovered the vortical nature, the rotation of the Great Red Spot long before it was observed by Pioneer 10.
We did work on the
clouds of Mars and the formation of high clouds over the volcanoes.
All that was done from the ground, but since that time I've been involved with Mariner 6 and 7, Mariner 9, and Viking, and finally Voyager.
As far as scientific accomplishment is concerned,
Probably Voyager just really has to be it.
The enormous amount of knowledge that came out of that program, the success of that program, has certainly been a highlight in my career.
Do you think NASA gives enough money for long-term data analysis after a mission is over and the pretty pictures have appeared in time?
No, that's always been a problem.
It continues as a problem today.
I think that there are people at NASA who understand this problem and are trying desperately to keep the funding going.
And there is an announcement right now, for example, for Neptune's, Voyager Neptune science
It's just one of the first things to go when budget cuts come in.
You've already gotten the data.
And if you don't analyze it this year, well, theoretically, you can do it next year or the year after.
One would hope that that situation, which is already improving, will continue to improve.
What's the state of planetary astronomy today?
Planetary astronomy as such is
not in very good shape, and it's really a result of the success of the space program.
Missions like Mariner, Viking, Voyager have learned so much about the planets that it's difficult to improve on that or to add incrementally to it from ground-based observations.
Surely there's a lot of work that can be done with small bodies, comets, asteroids,
These new objects that are being observed out in the so-called Kuiper Belt are extremely interesting.
And there are still good things that can be done from the ground.
The monitoring of the volcanic activity on Hio is an example of that, but it's not in the same
place that it was back during the 60s when almost everything you could do with new instrumentation was new and discoveries were being made one right after the other.
Could you give me a little summary of your schooling?
Yeah, I have a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering.
I got Northeastern University in 1954.
I then went into the Army from there to New Mexico State and probably set a record for the length of time anyone has ever spent obtaining a PhD.
I started taking courses in physics very early on in the late 50s.
And then got much more serious about it when the astronomy department was created in Mexico State.
Finally wrote my dissertation and got my PhD in 1972.
Do you think you talk to other types of astronomers more than you did, say, 20 years ago, or about the same, or less?
A lot more.
A lot more.
In fact, I'm really not doing very much in the way of planetary work right now.
I've gotten involved in some other things.
I think my interests have broadened considerably since I started.
You mentioned that there's still some looking down on planetary work.
Is there less of that than there was 20 or 30 years ago or about the same?
Very, very much less.
quite a number of years on the Telescope Allocation Committee at the University of Arizona.
And everybody who has been to Arizona is familiar with the arguments and fights that went on between Kuiper and Bach.
I mean, it's legendary, the way the two sides of the street looked at one another.
But during the time I spent on the TAC, I found that the so-called astrophysical people, stellar galactic
would very often speak up and support a proposal to do planetary work just as much as the planetary representatives.
I think a lot of that has gone away.
These things still exist.
I mentioned the cosmologists and the people who really look out to Hi-Z, kind of looking down on people who still poke around with globular clusters in their own galaxy and so on.
I think these things will always exist.
There's some pecking order that gets established somewhere.
What has the American taxpayer got out of planetary astronomy for the money they put in it?
Knowledge.
Do you think it's really had an effect?
An effect on what?
On the way people think about the universe or themselves or anything?
Absolutely had an effect on the way people think about the universe, without question.
I see that in talking to people on airplanes.
I mean, people really are a lot more savvy than a lot of the scientists give them credit for, just because.

And I think NASA deserves an enormous amount of credit for this, getting information out and making it available to the public and stimulating the production of various television series that have gotten the same information out in the public.
It could be a lot better, by the way.
NASA could...
could still improve its relationship with the education system in this country.
But I think what they've accomplished so far has been very useful, very effective.
On a personal note, when you meet somebody on an airplane sitting next to them or something and tell them you're an astronomer, what's the reaction you tend to get?
Oh, sort of awe.
Awe that they are actually sitting right next to an astronomer.
Do I spend all my time up on Mauna Kea?
Few people realize that astronomers spend less than 10% of their time collecting data and the other 90% trying to understand what it was that they got.
But, yeah, it's, wow, you're an astronomer.
Wow, what's new in the universe?
So it's favorable.
Oh, yeah, very, definitely.
All right, I'll let you.
